bibl.title: Letter from Grace T. Hallock to Philip Showalter Hench, September 5, 1940

div1.p: Hallock describes the sources for her article on Reed and yellow fever, responding to Hench's charge that her piece contains historical errors.

div1.head: Letter from Grace T. Hallock to Philip Showalter Hench, September 5, 1940
div1.opener:
METROPOLITAN LIFE INSURANCE COMPANY
FREDERICK H. ECKER, Chairman of the Board
LEROY A. LINCOLN, President
WELFARE DIVISION
----
DONALD B. ARMSTRONG, M.D.
Third Vice-President
ANTHONY J. LANZA, M.D.
Assistant Medical Director
NEW YORK CITY
September 5, 1940
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Dr. Armstrong has asked me to reply to your letter of
August 28th since I am one of the authors of the Health Heroes booklet on
Walter Reed and also of Health Through the Ages. Moreover, I had quite a
little to do with the preparation of the filmstrip on Walter Reed. In
the preparation of the filmstrip we had considerable assistance from Mrs.
Walter Reed who loaned us the photographs in her collection. Since this
filmstrip was made in 1927, I do not remember exactly which of the pic-
tures came from Mrs. Reed. I presume, however, that the ones showing Dr.
Reed in boyhood came originally from her. I have not seen or heard from
Mrs. Reed for a long time. Her summer address used to be Blue Ridge Summit,
Pa., and in the winter she resided at The Burlington, Vermont Avenue at
Thomas Circle, Washington, D. C. It is possible that you may already be
in touch with Mrs. Reed if she is still alive. I have never seen a notice
of her death.

I do not believe that an author may be permitted a little
license when teaching the public, if this license includes the use of cir-
cumstantial inaccuracies. With no thought of self-vindication, but only
because I believe you would like to know my sources, I am going to take up
the points you describe as “historical errors.” The drawing of Camp Lazear
on page 15 is an actual tracing of the photograph facing page 154 of Kelly's
Walter Reed and Yellow Fever. What you have taken to be high mountains is
our artist's conception of clouds. The dots to the left perhaps might be
construed as a flight of birds, although I am not sure of this. I suppose
the artist added these touches to dress up what seemed to him to be a par-
ticularly flat and drab-looking picture. What you have taken to be a river
is a path. I offer the same explanation for what appears to be a river in
the drawing on page 17. This is an exact tracing of the photograph facing
page 164 of Kelly's book. If you will examine the latter again, you will
notice a path which appears to go slightly uphill behind the fomites building.
This path in our drawing is colored yellow and we have a man walking along it.
The yellow strip in the background was put in, I presume, to add a touch of
color. I, too, have visited the site of Camp Lazear and can add my testimony
to the fact that it is definitely flat.

In regard to the diagram on page 21 and the accompanying
text on pages 19 and 20, the facts on which they are based are to be found
in an article by W. C. Gorgas, then Colonel of the Medical Corps, U. S.
Army, entitled “A Few General Directions with Regard to Destroying
Mosquitoes, Particularly the Yellow Fever Mosquito.” This article is
Part V (the last section) in Yellow Fever - A Compilation of Various
Publications, Senate Document #822. From your letter I presume that you
have this compilation. The passage from the Gorgas article is on page 243,
a copy of which I am enclosing for ready reference. It is true that this
account of the experiment differs in some of the details from that given
by Dr. Reed in his address, entitled “The Propagation of Yellow Fever -
Observations Based on Recent Researches,” pages 99-100 in the Senate
Document cited above, and also the account given by Dr. Carroll in “Yellow
Fever: A Popular Lecture,” on pages 210 and 211 of that Document. The
Gorgas account was, however, checked with those of Dr. Reed and Dr. Carroll
and one or two seeming discrepancies rectified, for example, you will
remember that Dr. Reed states (on page 99) that on the opposite side of
the screen (from Moran) were two “controls” and one other non-immune. This
accounts for the fact that there are three figures in the left box of the
second part of the diagram on page 21 of the Walter Reed booklet. The
Gorgas story was so clear cut that I used it for the sake of clarity. It
is possible, of course, that he was going on hearsay evidence and it might
have been better for me to have stuck to the Reed documents exclusively.

It has been a great pleasure to us to supply you with material
for your address and I sincerely hope that you will call on us again if we can
be of service.
